Notice in chapter 25, in verse number 13, as the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to them that sent him, for he refresheth the soul of his masters. We find that in chapter 28, in verse number 20, notice the first statement here. This is encouraging. The contrast there, but he that maketh haste to be rich shall not be innocent. He's speaking of stewards, and he says, moreover it is required in stewards that a man be found faithful. God didn't call every one of us to do the same thing. God didn't call everyone to be a Moses, amen? And some people said, praise the Lord, because I couldn't have led those people, amen? But God did call every one of us to be faithful, to be obedient, and to be intercessors. And that's an example that we see in Numbers 21 of Moses. See, each and every one of us can be an intercessor, amen? We can pray one for another. And by the way, we ought to be. Every one of us can be obedient to the decision that we make. We can obey or we disobey. There's really no middle ground. We find that this morning, just as Moses was obedient, every time God provides you or provides me with direction, there's a choice to be made. Will I obey or will I disobey? You say, why do you boil it down so basic? Because really that's just how basic it is. It's really just what it boils down to. And every single one of us can be faithful. It's a choice that we make. God requires faithfulness. He blesses faithfulness. He Himself is faithful. It's amazing. As we study the Word of God and we say, look, there's some things we can look at some people and say, well, I can't do that, I can't do that. God didn't call me to do that. It's fine. What did He call you to do? Be obedient and be faithful. And every single one of us, we can intercede, we can obey, and we can be faithful. It's just a matter of what we choose to do. So this morning as we look at Numbers 21, again, a familiar portion of Scripture, but as we focus in on the behavior of Moses, I hope this morning that we've been encouraged by Moses' behavior, that we would be thankful and rejoice just as the nation of Israel would have. Oh, Moses, we're thankful that you prayed because you got an answer. Oh, Moses, we're thankful that you obeyed because we have a solution, we have a remedy. We're thankful that you're faithful, Moses, because how would we have known otherwise? And we're encouraged by it. But I hope this morning we'd be challenged by it in our own lives, and we'd examine ourselves. Lord, how am I doing with the ministry of intercessory prayer? Am I really going to God on the behalf of others? What does my prayer life look like? God, how's my obedience? Is it immediate? Is it complete? God, how's my faithfulness? And as we look at this passage of Scripture, I hope that we could identify with Moses more than with the people, because the people, their soul was much discouraged because of the way they began to complain. We have no bread, we have no water, and this light bread, our soul loatheth this light bread. Oh, I hope that we could identify more with Moses than with the children of Israel, the people. Listen, it's easy to complain, it really is, but God says that we're to be thankful, we're to give thanks in everything, for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you. So, this morning, Moses prayed for the people, and I hope that as we examine these three aspects of the behavior of Moses, that we just evaluate our own lives, say, God, would You use us? Would You use us in our little place, in our little opportunity of influence? Use us, God, for Your glory. Listen, we've been given, we've been entrusted with truth. When Brother Michael shared from that prayer letter, and I'm thankful that he gave the numbers, 30 people that are out weekly sharing the gospel, that's encouraging, that's exciting, that's convicting, and what a joy to know that we can be faithful in our little place where God has put us to do what God's called us to do. We thank You for this great account of Your provision for Your people, and Lord, how they confessed their sin and they received an answer as Moses prayed, and God, You provided them with deliverance. We thank You for Your grace and for Your mercy. We thank You for the picture of Calvary, and how Jesus referred to this passage of Scripture speaking about the substitutionary atonement of the Lord Jesus Christ on the cross of Calvary, and how thankful we are that Jesus went to that cruel cross. He suffered, He bled and died, He was buried in a borrowed tomb, and He rose conquering sin, death, and the grave. We thank You that He lives forevermore. We thank You that You have called us to be Your servants and Your ministers, and I pray that as we examine this passage this morning that You'd help us, Lord, to be encouraged by the behavior of Moses more than being encouraged by his behavior. I pray, God, that You'd use Your Word to challenge us. Lord, that we would evaluate our intercession, our obedience, and our faithfulness. Lord, use us for Your honor and for Your glory.
